questions.prompt: In circuit theory, which of the following is the correct definition of a two-terminal resistor?
options: A) A physical component that obeys Ohm's law with a fixed resistance R
B) Any two-terminal element whose voltage and current satisfy f(v, i) = 0
C) A component that always dissipates power as heat
D) A device with resistance measured in ohms
questions.correctAnswer: B) Any two-terminal element whose voltage and current satisfy f(v, i) = 0
questions.explanation: In circuit theory, a resistor is defined generally as any two-terminal element with a v-i relationship f(v, i) = 0. This includes nonlinear devices, sources, and more.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT a two-terminal resistor in circuit theory?
options: A) An ideal diode
B) A DC voltage source
C) A three-terminal transistor
D) An open circuit
questions.explanation: A transistor has three terminals, so it is not a two-terminal resistor. All the other options have exactly two terminals and a v-i relationship.

questions.prompt: The v-i characteristic of a device is described by the set R = {(v, i) : v - i^3 = 0}. Is this a resistor in circuit theory?
options: A) No, because the relationship is nonlinear
B) No, because it doesn't obey Ohm's law
C) Yes, because voltage and current satisfy f(v, i) = 0
D) Yes, but only if R is positive
questions.correctAnswer: C) Yes, because voltage and current satisfy f(v, i) = 0
questions.explanation: Any two-terminal element whose v and i satisfy f(v, i) = 0 is a resistor. Linearity is not required. Here f(v, i) = v - i^3 = 0 qualifies.

questions.prompt: On the v-i plane, which variable is on the horizontal axis?
options: A) Current i
B) Voltage v
C) Power p
D) Resistance R
questions.explanation: By convention, in the 'v-i plane', the first variable (v) is the horizontal axis (abscissa) and the second variable (i) is the vertical axis (ordinate).

questions.prompt: A DC current source supplies i = 5A regardless of the voltage across it. In circuit theory, this device is:
options: A) Not a resistor because its current is constant
B) A linear resistor with infinite resistance
C) A two-terminal resistor with characteristic i = 5 for all v
D) An active element that cannot be classified as a resistor
questions.correctAnswer: C) A two-terminal resistor with characteristic i = 5 for all v
questions.explanation: A DC current source has f(v, i) = i - 5 = 0, which satisfies the general resistor definition. Its v-i characteristic is a horizontal line at i = 5.

questions.prompt: What distinguishes a time-varying resistor from a time-invariant one?
options: A) A time-varying resistor is nonlinear; a time-invariant one is linear
B) A time-varying resistor's v-i relationship changes with time
C) A time-varying resistor can only carry AC current
D) There is no difference; all resistors are time-invariant
questions.correctAnswer: B) A time-varying resistor's v-i relationship changes with time
questions.explanation: A time-varying resistor has a v-i relationship that depends on time, e.g., v(t) = R(t) * i(t) where R(t) changes. A time-invariant resistor has a fixed v-i relationship.

questions.prompt: If you reflect the v-i characteristic of a resistor about the line v = i (the 45-degree line through the origin), what do you obtain?
options: A) The i-v characteristic of the same resistor
B) The v-i characteristic of its dual resistor
C) The power characteristic of the resistor
D) The inverse resistance
questions.correctAnswer: B) The v-i characteristic of its dual resistor
questions.explanation: Reflecting about the 45-degree line swaps the v and i axes, which transforms the v-i representation into the i-v representation. The dual resistor's v-i characteristic in the v-i plane equals the original resistor's characteristic in the i-v plane.

questions.prompt: Which statement best explains why the broad circuit theory definition of 'resistor' is practically useful?
options: A) It simplifies manufacturing of physical resistors
B) Analysis techniques developed for resistors apply to all two-terminal devices
C) It eliminates the need to use Ohm's law
D) It makes nonlinear devices behave linearly
questions.correctAnswer: B) Analysis techniques developed for resistors apply to all two-terminal devices
questions.explanation: The practical power of the broad definition is that series/parallel rules, graphical analysis, and other resistor analysis techniques apply to any device classified as a resistor, not just linear ones.

questions.prompt: A device has the v-i characteristic: v = 0 for i > 0, and i = 0 for v < 0. What type of resistor is this?
options: A) A linear resistor
B) A short circuit
C) An ideal diode
D) An open circuit
questions.explanation: This describes the ideal diode: when forward biased (i > 0), the voltage is zero (acts as short circuit); when reverse biased (v < 0), the current is zero (acts as open circuit).

questions.prompt: The characteristic R = {(v, i) : v = 3.3V for all i} describes which device?
options: A) A linear resistor of 3.3 ohms
B) A DC current source of 3.3A
C) A DC voltage source of 3.3V
D) An open circuit with 3.3V across it
questions.correctAnswer: C) A DC voltage source of 3.3V
questions.explanation: If v = 3.3V regardless of the current, the device maintains a constant voltage. This is the definition of an ideal DC voltage source. Its v-i characteristic is a vertical line at v = 3.3 on the v-i plane.
